child.geography: spoken on Guadalcanal island, forming a chain extending west to east along the southern coast from Mbolonda Bay almost to Marau Sound.

child.pub-comments: “Malango and Mbirao are each represented in the sample by a single communalect” (Pawley 2011:3-4).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
child.geography: spoken in the inland of Guadalcanal island, in the hills and lowlands to the east of Malango, and is bounded by Longgu in the north and Marau in the east.

child.pub-comments: “The claim here is that the first detectable split within GN [Guadalcanal-Nggelic] was a dialectal divergence of the ancestor of Talise and Mbirao, two very similar languages of southeast Guadalcanal” (Pawley 2011:12).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: Pawley (2011:5) notes that Aula/Aola is “probably a dialect of Gela” (see table 1), but also mentions that native Lengo speakers consider Aola to be a dialect of Lengo (see Pawley 2011:, footnote 2).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: Pawley states that Tintogomu is “possibly a dialect of Lengo” (Pawley 2011:5, table 1).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “Paul Unger (pers.comm.) says that Lengo speakers distinguish five dialects, which they call Ghaobata […], Tasiboko and Reko […], Paripao […], and Aola […]. They regard Ghaimuta […] as a 'different language', an indication that it is the most divergent of the communalects Tryon and Hackman asign to Lengo. It scores only 73 percent with the Lengo communalect. Unger thinks that Tasiboko may equate with the “Lengo” dialect of Lengo [...]” (Pawley 2011:3, footnote 2).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
child.geography: spoken in the central north coast of the Guadalcanal island and parts of the hill country to the south

child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
child.geography: spoken along the coast of Guadalcanal island, a chain running from Honiara westward to Cape Esperance, then following the west coast southward as far as Mbolonda Bay

child.pub-comments: “Malango and Mbirao are each represented in the sample by a single communalect” (Pawley 2011:3-4).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
child.geography: spoken in central Guadalcanal island, occupying scattered pockets in the foothills on the northern flanks of the central range/cordillera in central Guadalcanal

child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “After the divergence of Nggelic, and the establishment of a denser population along the Guadalcanal coast, all the communalects of Guadalcanal, including those of the southeast, continued to be part of a loose network. […] One consequence was that some Southeast Guadalcanal languages now share many isoglosses with neighboring North and West languages apart from Nggelic. In effect, there was a partial resynthesis of Southeast Guadalcanal with North and West Guadalcanal, so that these came to form a secondary subgroup” (Pawley 2011:13).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: Pawley (2011:5) notes that Aula/Aola is “probably a dialect of Gela” (see table 1), but also mentions that native Lengo speakers consider Aola to be a dialect of Lengo (see Pawley 2011:, footnote 2).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “The hypothesis is that after Guadalcanal-Nggelic speakers occupied the south coast of Guadalcanal, they had very limited contacts with those occupying the north coast. There was much freer communication between the Florida Islands and the north coast. The Florida group lies off the coast of north Guadalcanal, could easily be reached by sea, and was probably settled at least as early as north Guadalcanal” (Pawley 2011:12-13).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
child.geography: spoken on the small Florida island group, also known as Nggela or Gela, consisting of two main islands Nggela Sule and Nggela Pile, and many smaller islands. It lies off the north coast of Guadalcanal, almost halfway to the eastern tip of Santa Isabel

child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “Nuclear GN [Guadalcanal-Nggelic] divided into a Nggelic dialect area, from which Gela and Bugotu derive, and a North and West Guadalcanal dialect area, ancestral to (I) the West Guadalcanal dialect cluster, (ii) the Lengo dialect cluster […], and (iii) Malango […]” (Pawley 2011:13).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “After the divergence of Nggelic, and the establishment of a denser population along the Guadalcanal coast, all the communalects of Guadalcanal, including those of the southeast, continued to be part of a loose network. […] One consequence was that some Southeast Guadalcanal languages now share many isoglosses with neighboring North and West languages apart from Nggelic. In effect, there was a partial resynthesis of Southeast Guadalcanal with North and West Guadalcanal, so that these came to form a secondary subgroup” (Pawley 2011:13).

Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: “It is noteworthy that Guadalcanal-Nggelic [GN] exhibits much less internal lexical diversity than Cristobal-Malaitan [CM], with all GN languages but one sharing at least 50 percent on the 200-item list. This suggests that GN remained a single dialect network for a good deal longer than CM. The one lexicostatistical outlier is Bugotu, whose figures have been greatly deflated by borrowing from Santa Isabel languages” (Pawley 2011:5).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

child.pub-comments: Pawley states that “the degree and pattern of lexicostatistical diversity within the Southeast Solomons languages indicates that the CM [Cristobal-Malaitan] branch of Southeast Solomonic diverged from the GN [Guadalcanal-Nggelic] branch at least 2,000 years ago” (2011:4).
child.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.

root.publications: Pawley, Andrew K. 2011. On the Position of Bugotu and Gela in the Guadalcanal-Nggelic Subgroup of Oceanic, Oceanic Linguistics, no. 1 edn., vol. 50, 1-24.
